data.title: Dusty house? How to make your home dust-free - and KEEP it that way
data.meta_description: DUST buildup will have become a regular source of frustration for millions of people thanks to the pandemic, which has emphasised staying at home wherever possible for months on end. How do you keep your home dust-free?
data.text:
DUST buildup will have become a regular source of frustration for millions of people thanks to the pandemic, which has emphasised staying at home wherever possible for months on end. How do you keep your home dust-free?

By Liam Doyle, News Reporter

Link copied Bookmark

Lynsey Queen of Clean shares recipe for fabric refresher spray

Dust and dirt is a problem most people associate with absence or negligence. However, the opposite is also true, as increased activity in one area can stir patches lying all over the home. With most people shut away at home for their jobs, some will spend more than eight extra hours at home per day, meaning they need to redouble efforts to keep everything clean and tidy.

How can you keep your home dust-free?

Dirt can come from many sources, meaning people must stay vigilant to hold it back.

Matthew Harrison and Edward Jonkler of PriceYourJob and Remora Cleaning LTD offered Express.co.uk advice on keeping everything clean.

Their combined knowledge could save people a lot of tidying time they could be using for some R&R.

READ MORE: Baking soda for cleaning: 6 little known ways to use baking soda

Declutter

Anyone wanting to reduce dust and dirt clutter can unburden themselves with some organisation.

Mr Harrison said: "One of the biggest dust culprits is clutter, so if you have many decorative items or magazine in your living room, you may want to get rid of some to reduce the amount of dust.

"This will not only reduce clutter but will also make your home much cleaner and more spacious."

Invalid email

Use your vacuum

Mr Jonkler added those wanting to de-clutter should use specific vacuum attachments.

These should prevent dust from being displaced rather than extracted altogether.

He said: “The best thing to do is to de-clutter, then rather than dust with a duster or cloth, use a vacuum with a brush attachment, this sucks up dust instead of throwing it around the room.

"The less dry and damp wiping with cloths you do, on natural surfaces and painted surfaces, the longer they will hold up well.”

DON'T MISS

Wash sofa throws

Blankets and sofa covers also attract dust, whether in regular use or not.

Mr Harrison advised people to wash them now and again to get some of it out.

He urged anyone attempting this to ensure they are washer-compatible first, otherwise they can hand wash them with soap and water.

Invest in an air purifier

Air purifiers, like humidifiers and conditioners, help improve air quality by room.

Mr Harrison said: "These are designed to collect and trap dust particles that enter your home through open doors or windows.

"When choosing an air purifier, make sure you select one with a HEPA filter and place it near doors and windows to ensure it collects as much dust and hair as possible.”
